title: Lynn Swann Resigns as USC’s Athletic Director
text:
University of Southern California athletic director Lynn Swann resigned on Monday, months after his department became entangled in a wide-ranging college admissions scandal.

In a letter released by the university, USC president Carol Folt described the move as Swann’s decision and praised his three years in one of the premier administrative jobs in college sports. Swann, a 67-year-old former NFL star who was an All-American wide receiver for the Trojans, could not immediately be reached for comment.

Folt praised Swann’s “historic contributions” to USC, citing the school’s five national championships in various sports since he took the helm in 2016 and record-high graduation rates for athletes.

But with USC firmly at the center of the nationwide college-admissions cheating case, it has been a turbulent year for the Trojans. Folt took over as the president at USC in July, promising to “get it right” and figure out the best management team to support her. Prosecutors say USC officials helped facilitate admission to the private university for more than two dozen students as recruited athletes, often when those teens weren’t competitive players. Four former USC employees—three coaches and an athletic-department administrator—have been charged in the scheme. Many of the families were admitted before Swann took over the athletics department, and a person familiar with the matter has said his predecessor, Pat Haden, is of interest to investigators. However, Swann was athletic director when a number of families gained fraudulent admission to the school as purported rowers and other athletes, prosecutors say. Though prosecutors have described USC as a victim in the case, the school actually profited from it in some ways. Singer’s clients allegedly paid more than $1.3 million to USC accounts controlled by former senior associate athletic director Donna Heinel between 2014 and 2018, mainly an account for the USC Women’s Athletic Board. And a bank account that funded the water polo program received payments totaling $250,000, prosecutors say. Heinel has pleaded not guilty. Her attorney, Nina Marino, said last week, “Donna performed her job in accordance with Pat Haden’s (and later Lynn Swann’s) expectations as well as those of the USC administration.” Swann’s resignation came just days after USC’s football program returned to the Top 25 in the Associated Press poll following a 45-20 victory over Stanford. The Trojans, who failed to make the preseason Top 25 for the first time since 2001, are ranked No. 24 in this week’s poll. Folt said Dave Roberts, currently a special advisor to her, would serve as interim athletics director and named a committee to conduct a national search for a permanent replacement. —Jennifer Levitz contributed to this report.
